Dear Ms. Vasilovski:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 3/28/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
One of eight foster care files, held a parent agency treatment plan that was not
signed by the parent. There was no documentation to indicate the report was
reviewed with and provided to the parent.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/28/24 Interim, CAP approved 4/22/24

CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Two of three adoptive family evaluations were not completed within the required
timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/28/24 Interim, CAP approved 4/22/24.
4/12/23 Renewal, CAP approved 5/1/23.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Borrowed Bed- The agency’s borrowed bed agreement currently indicates the
date the agreement was approved by the foster parent. However, the agency
was advised to add how the foster parent was contacted and that they were
willing to accept the child.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The CAP approved 4/22/24, was developed as a result of the 3/28/25 interim
review. The agency was cited regarding immunizations, parent agency treatment
plan signatures, and adoption evaluation timeliness. The agency implemented
their CAP and reported partial compliance this year. There were two repeat
violations during the 2025 review regarding PATP signatures and timely adoptive
evaluations.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator (CA) assessment dated 3/10/25 was reviewed and
discussed on-site. The CA reported continued efforts to improve compliance in the
areas cited during the 2024 review. The CA indicated additional supervisory
oversight, reporting, spreadsheet trackers, and report approval checklists have
been used. The agency will continue to develop strategies to address the repeat
violations found during the 2025 review. The agency did not identify any barriers
or systemic factors that impacted compliance. The CA reported three disrupted
placements during this review period. One child was removed and placed in
detention, due to ongoing issues in the home and the relative caregiver’s
unwillingness to continue placement. The second child changed placement due to
the relative caregiver having an unexpected health crisis. The third child changed
placement due to their diabetic medical needs not being met by the relative
caregiver.
Financial Overview
The agency’s 2024 financial audit, 2024 and 2025 budget were reviewed. No
financial concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. Both staff reported being satisfied in their
current positions. Staff stated their supervisors are supportive, available, helpful,
knowledgeable, and overall wonderful. Staff indicated they have plenty of
interesting and useful training opportunities available. No concerns were reported
by staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as last year. The building
has sufficient space for staff to work and hold meetings. The office has locking
storage for files and adequate space for clients to meet with staff or have family
visitation.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three identified safety alerts.

Safety Alert 1: During a visit on 10/30/24 the home was observed to be missing a
smoke detector outside of the child’s bedroom, and hallway outside of the other
bedrooms.
Resolution 1: On 10/31/24 the family installed a smoke detector outside of the
children’s bedroom and in the hallway outside of the other bedrooms, as verified by
agency staff. Photos were provided to DCWL for verification.
Safety Alert 2: During a visit on 10/28/24 the home was observed to be missing a
smoke detector in the hallway of the sleeping area.
Resolution 2: On 10/29/24 the family was provided a smoke detector, which was
installed in the hallway of the sleeping area. Photos were provided to DCWL for
verification.
Safety Alert 3: During a visit on 11/1/24 the home was observed to be missing a
smoke detector in the basement. Additionally, the home had a koi pond outside, with
a fence and a floatation device. The family had a door alarm, but it was not in place
during the visit.
Resolution 3: On 11/4/24 the agency provided the family with a new smoke detector
for the basement and a door alarm. Photos were provided to DCWL to verify both
items were installed and in use.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
